messageBody:
On 31/07/07, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:

> On 7/31/07, Nat Pryce <nat.pryce@...> wrote:
> Using a sound implementation for a singleton (e.g. dependency
> injection) is similar to leveraging the compiler to minimize mistakes:
> I'd rather trust the compiler to enforce a good practice than vague
> social recommendations that risk to be ignored for various reasons
> (and even by the best developers).
>
> > If members of the team don't understand the architecture then tech
> > huddles and a big visible architecture diagram can help.
>
> This is a very idealistic view of things. In teams of dozens of
> programmers of various age and seniority levels scattered over
> multiple time zones, mentoring and diagrams only go so far. The only
> way to guarantee that things don't break is to leverage your
> programming language to make sure that any infraction will simply not
> compile.

...

I agree, the larger the teams and the less skilled the personnel the
more effort you have to spend ensuring that architectural constraints
are maintained, the more time needs to be spent on communication and
knowledge sharing and the slower the communication has to be.

However, relying on the compiler to *enforce* constraints is not, in
my experience, the answer because it requires developers to have a
good understanding of the language semantics, not write poor code and
not just change the code to work around what they see as barriers in
the way of their work. Which requires good developers in the first
place, who don't need to be constrained.

For example, the Singleton pattern cannot be implemented in Java yet
I've seen teams try anyway, attempt to apply C++ idioms to Java code,
and then wonder why their code doesn't work when run in a container.

In my experience, it's better to use the language to *encourage* good
practice. That is, provide code that makes it easier to do the right
thing than the wrong thing -- programmers are lazy by nature.
"Dependency Injection" is a good example. If the system is written in
a good DI style then the code exposes dependencies between decoupled
objects and singletons are not necessary. The "just create one"
pattern works fine because it takes less code to wire a new object
into the right part of the object graph than it does to write a
singleton class.
